results.title: I Look up, I look down
results.brief_description: A body falls gracefully through the air, kilometres from the earth, seeming to hover between falling, then rising again in a fluid dance that suspends and evades gravity. This looping video installation playfully dispels any laws of science as the casually dressed skydiver that we see floating through the air never gets closer to the ground. Moving hypnotically around the camera the body disorients all sense of up and down until at one point it seems to float, buffeted by the air, toward a passing plane.

results.title: The Illustrated Auschwitz
results.creator_credit: Lucia Salinas Briones, Jackie Farkas and AFTRS
results.brief_description: Jackie Farkas uses the extraordinary and harrowing oral testimony of an elderly Hungarian woman as the basis for a poetic and abstract investigation into how cinema can ‘illustrate’ such profoundly horrendous experiences. The use of found footage, elusive images of beauty and horror and sequences from ‘The Wizard of Oz’ to elucidate the narrator’s memories creates an extraordinary representation of the holocaust experience, of survival, of home and memory, and of how we can comprehend the incomprehensible.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lucia Salinas Briones, Jackie Farkas and AFTRS

results.title: Night cries: a rural tragedy
results.brief_description: In Tracey Moffatt’s re-imaging of the pivotal Australian film “Jedda”, a middle-aged Aboriginal woman returns to her outback home to nurse her dying white mother. Filmed against lushly coloured sets that recall the technicolour glories of the past, and utilising a harsh discordant soundscape, “Night Cries” occupies the landscape of dreams and the classic mythic terrain of familial violence and betrayal. This short film does more than simply reconfigure and re-imagine past narratives. It inaugurated a clear and permament break with previous moving image representations of the “outback”: no longer the pretence that it is a place outside language and history.

results.title: Private eye
results.creator_credit: Tasfilm Productions, Tasmania Dept. of Labour and Industry and Peter McKinley
results.brief_description:
This 1970 film demonstrates the importance of eye safety and shows various methods of protection. The film opens with a sequence in film noir style of a ‘private eye’ working a case, with this gimmick interspersed throughout the film. It shows industrial working scenarios and various examples of eye protection, including safety glasses and helmets with visors.

Produced by Tasfilm Productions for the Department of Labour and Industry, Tasmania, and presented by Protector Sureguard.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Two Girls and a Baby
results.creator_credit: Annamax Media, Penny Robins and Kelli Simpson
results.brief_description: An entertaining look at the IVF process from the point of view of a lesbian couple as they deal with sperm banks, relationships, baby clothes, and community resistance.

results.title: Children of the Musgraves (A)
results.creator_credit: Peerless Films, J. Campbell Dobbie and Edmee Campbell-Dobbie
results.brief_description: Filmed at Ernabella Mission Station in the Musgrave Ranges, 1000 miles north of Adelaide. Shows the life of Aborigines, their schooling and play, and their assimilation to white Australian ways. They are also given time each day to follow their own cultural traditions of hunting and cooking. Narrated by J.J. Hume.

results.title: Flame of Persia
results.brief_description: A historical, geographical and descriptive account of Persia/Iran including the celebration of 25 centuries of monarchy. Depicts the Shah of Iran discussing Persian industry and pride. Narrated by Orson Welles.

results.title: Homosexuality: a film for discussion
results.brief_description: Designed to dispel the myths about homosexuality. Homosexuals talk about their lives, their relationships and the difficulties of growing up gay in an oppressive, intolerant society. Parents of gays speak out and the Melbourne public expresses its view on the subject.

results.title: Neat on Paper
results.creator_credit: Sydney Filmmakers' Co-op Action Group, Mandy King, James Kesteven and Miriana Marusic
results.brief_description: The Sydney Filmmakers’ Co-operative was a major national agency for the distribution and exhibition of independently produced Australian film and video for over 20 years. This program examines the issues surrounding its closure in 1986.

results.title: Boys and Balls
results.creator_credit: Gil Scrine Films, Film Finance Corporation Australia, Thermal Falls, Anna Grieve and Sue Thomson
results.brief_description: It is in games many men discover their paradise. Robert Lynd. H.G. Nelson (Greig Pickhaver) and Rampaging Roy Slaven (John Doyle) host an amusing, often hilarious exploration of the fascination of men with balls; whether it is a cricket, football, tennis, basketball, soccer, bowls, table tennis, hockey or golf ball! Celebrities including Ted Whitten, Ron Barassi, Merv Hughes, Derek Kickett, Andrew Gaze, Lindsay Gaze, Francis Awaritife, Brad Mackay, Greg Champion and the average bloke and kid next door share favourite childhood memories of their sporting idols, humerous moments, coaching temperaments, the importance of rules and umpiring, and the incidence of sporting violence. Interviews, archival footage and famous quotes are intermixed in this perceptive program.
